questions.text: A gentleman presents to the OPD with a saddle nose deformity. He gives a past history of cough, on/off fever, and hemoptysis. On examination, septal perforation is present with pale granuloma. His chest x-ray showed multiple cavitary lesions, and the biopsy showed granuloma, multinucleate giant cells, and caseous necrosis. What would be the probable cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

In a patient with saddle nose deformity, septal perforation with pale granuloma and caseous necrosis on biopsy is consistent with tuberculosis (TB). The history of fever, cough, and hemoptysis along with cavitary lesions on chest x-ray support the diagnosis of TB.

questions.text: Foreign body entry into the laryngeal inlet is prevented by the cough reflex. This reflex is sluggish in alcohol ingestion and some other conditions. Which nerve is likely injured?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The internal laryngeal nerve is the nerve implicated in the inhibition of the cough reflex in an alcoholic. Alcohol can cause chemical irritation of the nerve and it is also a potent inhibitor of the central nervous system. The cough reflex is a protective mechanism of the larynx to expel irritants and keep the airway clear. Chemical or mechanical irritation of the respiratory mucosa stimulates the afferent internal laryngeal nerve, which is the branch of the superior laryngeal nerve of the vagus nerve.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents with complaints of nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip. There is a past history of FESS for failed conservative management 5 years ago. Uncinectomy and maxillary ostium dilation was done during the previous FESS. A DNE done now shows patent ostia and mucosal edema of the maxillary sinus lining. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The history of nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip and endoscopy showing mucosal edema is suggestive of acute rhinosinusitis. The next best step in management is symptomatic treatment with nasal steroid irrigation, decongestants, and antihistamines, regardless of the patient's past history of FESS operation.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man has been diagnosed with oropharyngeal carcinoma. Which of the following group of lymph nodes does the sentinel node belong to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Level 2

The jugulodigastric node is the sentinel lymph node and belongs to the level 2 group of lymph nodes. This is the node enlarged in both tonsillitis and base of tongue carcinoma as lymphatics from the oropharynx drain into the upper jugular chain.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with multiple nodules in the nasal mucosa. Biopsy from the nodules revealed the presence of Miculikz cells and Russell bodies. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Rhinoscleroma

The given clinical scenario and the biopsy findings showing Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies are characteristic of rhinoscleroma. Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus).

questions.text: In a patient presenting with a conductive type of hearing loss, a negative Rinne test with a 512 Hz tuning fork indicates a minimum air-bone gap of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

30 dB
The negative Rinne test for 512 Hz indicates a minimum air-bone gap of 30 dB. Rinne’s test is a tuning fork test performed commonly with tuning forks of frequencies such as 128, 256, 512, and 1024 Hz. Rinne’s test is done by placing a vibrating tuning fork on the patient’s mastoid and when he stops hearing, it is brought beside the external auditory meatus (EAC).

questions.text: A patient comes with an ulcer on the tongue with a duration of 3 months. On examination, there is a 3.5 cm x 2.5 cm lesion with induration of 8 mm. There was no lymphadenopathy. What is the stage of this lesion according to 8th AJCC guidelines?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Stage II
The maximum diameter of the ulcer is less than 2-4 cm and the depth of invasion is less than 10mm which implies T2; There is no lymph node involvement (NO) and no metastasis (MO). A T2N0M0 tumor is classified as stage II according to the 8th AJCC guidelines.

questions.text: An ENT resident is evaluating a patient with suspected allergic rhinitis. On anterior rhinoscopy, which of the following is most likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Pale and edematous mucosa

A patient with perennial allergic rhinitis will have a pale and edematous nasal mucosa with swollen turbinates. Crusts that bleed on removal and atrophied turbinates are features seen in atrophic rhinitis.

questions.text: A 19-year-old boy complains of being bullied in school for his high-pitched voice. A Gutzmann’s pressure test is done which helps you to diagnose his condition. What condition does he have?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Puberphonia
The given clinical scenario with a positive Gutzmann’s pressure test is suggestive of puberphonia. It is a condition seen in emotionally labile adolescent males. They continue to speak in the prepubertal high pitched voice.

questions.text: While performing tympanoplasty, the ENT surgeon notices that the floor of the middle ear is deficient. Which of the following structures is susceptible to injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Internal jugular vein

The internal jugular vein is susceptible to injury in this given clinical scenario. The floor of the middle ear is related to the internal jugular vein. Occasionally, the floor is deficient and the jugular bulb is then covered only by fibrous tissue and a mucous membrane making it susceptible to injury during middle ear surgery.

questions.text: A child with protruding ears is brought to the OPD by his worried parents. They opt for surgical correction of the defect due to cosmetic reasons. After what age would you proceed with the surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

6 years
Protruding ears or bat ears can be corrected anytime after 6 years of age if cosmetic appearance demands. This is due to the fact that the pinna is completely developed and achieves adult configuration by the age of 6 years.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman with a family history of hearing loss in her mother developed a hearing problem during pregnancy. Hearing loss is bilateral and progressive. Which of the following is the single best investigation to establish a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Impedance audiometry
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of otosclerosis and the single best investigation to diagnose otosclerosis is impedance audiometry.

questions.text: A patient presents to your OPD with hearing difficulty and scanty, foul-smelling discharge from the left ear. Otologic examination reveals the following finding. What is the treatment of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Mastoidectomy
The given clinical scenario describes a case of atticoantral type of CSOM and modified radical mastoidectomy is the treatment of choice here.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with throat pain, fever, and ear pain. He is diagnosed with recurrent tonsillitis. Which nerve is responsible for the ear pain in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve
The tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis.

questions.text: You are the ENT resident performing a direct laryngoscopy procedure on a patient and report the presence of a laryngocele. The given condition is due to an enlarged diverticulum from which part of the larynx?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Saccule of ventricle
Laryngocele arises from the saccule of the ventricle. It is an abnormal dilation of the laryngeal saccule and extends beyond the thyroid cartilage and the ventricle.

questions.text: A known case of right-sided nasopharyngeal carcinoma now presents with drooping of eyelids, reduced sweating on the right side of the face, and constricted pupil. Involvement of which of the following structures leads to these features?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Sympathetic chain
Involvement of the sympathetic chain causes these features. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Horner’s syndrome secondary to nasopharyngeal carcinoma involving the cervical sympathetic chain.

questions.text: A patient with acute coalescent mastoiditis undergoes cortical mastoidectomy. Which of the following is used as a surgical landmark to locate the mastoid antrum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Macewen’s triangle 

Macewen’s (suprameatal) triangle is used as a surgical landmark to locate the mastoid antrum. In an adult, the antrum lies 12-15 mm from the surface. This triangle is also the site of tenderness in acute mastoiditis.

questions.text: A 48-year old construction worker presents to you with hearing loss. His audiogram reveals a diagnosis of noise-induced hearing loss. Which organ is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Organ of Corti 
The organ of Corti is the sensory organ of hearing and is situated on the basilar membrane. Chronic exposure to loud noises may mechanically damage the organ of Corti and result in noise induced hearing loss.

questions.text: You suspect a temporal bone fracture in a patient who presented with right side facial weakness, decreased hearing, vertigo, and bleeding from the ear. What is the investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

HRCT
HRCT (High-resolution CT) is the investigation of choice for the temporal bone fractures complicated by facial nerve palsy or CSF leak.

questions.text: A patient undergoes surgery of the lateral part of the base of the skull. Postoperatively, the patient presents with aspiration but does not have a change in voice. Which of the following is the reason?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Superior laryngeal nerve injury
In the given clinical scenario, the patient experiences aspiration but does not exhibit any change in voice following base of skull surgery. This suggests an injury to the superior laryngeal nerve (SLN).
